Damn. Turns out, this was happening because I had enabled offline mode for Gradle, which is weird because Android Studio previously used to show a message when enabled.

Sorry for disturbing. Please close this issue :)

I'd originally intended to split in the center, but the designer I'm working with pointed out that we have content that extends beyond the midpoint but should be aligned to one grid or the other.  Right-aligned content seemed unusual enough not to bother with, but in retrospect that's pretty weak.

I like the gravity idea! Instead of a split grid, allow specifying a grid for each From origin, with optional max size.  Maybe specify color for each grid as well, allowing them to overlap.  Keep the existing methods for the basic behavior of a single unbounded grid anchored at TOP.

Something roughly like this:

``` java
class DesignSpec {
  public static final Keyline UNBOUNDED = // ...
  public static final int DEFAULT_COLOR = // ...

  public DesignSpec setBaselineGrid(From from, Keyline limit, int color) { /* .. */ }
}
```

i.e.

``` java
spec
  .setBaselineGrid(From.TOP, DesignSpec.UNBOUNDED, DesignSpec.DEFAULT_COLOR)
  .setBaselineGrid(From.BOTTOM, new Keyline(48, From.BOTTOM), res.getColor(android.R.color.white))
  // ...
```

If that sounds good to you, let's close this PR and I'll send you a new one.
The only ugly bit is that the limit's From needs to be parallel to the grid's From, but that can be checked at runtime.
The same here. Thanks @hugocroch for the fix, it worked for both the RIGHT and BOTTOM cases.
